greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Maximal digit value in primorial base expansion of A276086(A276086(A276086(n))), where A276086(n) converts primorial base expansion of n into its prime product form.
comment: In range n = 0 .. 32768, a(n) attains the maximum possible value A000040(A328406(n))-1 only at n=2 and n=2804, when it must be the value of the most significant digit in the primorial base expansion of A328403(n).

When comparing the scatter plots of this sequence and those of A328389 and A328394, although the overall shape gets more blurred on each iteration of A276086, it is easy to see by informal inductive reasoning that the low values of the sequences should occur at about same positions.
Question: Are there any 1's after a(0), a(1) and a(4)?
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..32768
Index entries for sequences related to primorial base
mathematica: Block[{b = MixedRadix[Reverse@ Prime@ Range@ 120], f}, f[n_] := Times @@ Power @@@ # &@ Transpose@{Prime@ Range@ Length@ #, Reverse@ #} &@ IntegerDigits[n, b]; Array[Max@ IntegerDigits[Nest[f, #, 3], b] &, 79, 0]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Oct 17 2019 *)
program: A276086(n) = { my(m=1, p=2); while(n, m *= (p^(n%p)); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); (m); };
A328114(n) = { my(s=0, p=2); while(n, s = max(s,n%p); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); (s); };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 16 2019
